author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Xi, Putin and Trump: The Strongmen Follies
description: This is what happens when a leader wants to be the president for life.
content: The last five years have been a master class in comparative politics, because something happened that we’d never seen before at the same time: The world’s three most powerful leaders — Vladimir Putin, Xi Jinping and Donald Trump — each took drastic steps to hold onto power beyond their designated terms of office. One failed. Two succeeded. And therein lies a tale that says so much about our world today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Is Slang as Swell as It Used to Be? Yas!
description: But these days it’s easier to preserve it on the record.
content: The first Looney Tunes star character, before Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck and the others, was a blandly joyous little Mickey Mouse knockoff named Bosko. Obsessives of ancient cartoons have long delighted in the possibility that in one 1933 short, Bosko dropped an F-bomb. Listen for yourself here at about 5:34.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Bitcoin Miners Want to Recast Themselves as Eco-Friendly
description: Facing intense criticism, the crypto mining industry is trying to change the view that its energy-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate.
content: Along a dirt-covered road deep in Texas farm country, the cryptocurrency company Argo Blockchain is building a power plant for the internet age: a crypto “mining” site stocked with computers that generate new Bitcoins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Zelizer
title: What Is Georgia’s Political Future?
description: Greg Bluestein’s “Flipped” argues that Georgian voters are turning away from the Republican Party.
content: FLIPPEDHow Georgia Turned Purple and Broke the Monopoly on Republican PowerBy Greg Bluestein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Ada Hegerberg Wants to See How Good She Can Be
description: The world’s best women’s player lost nearly two years to injury. Now she’s back and eager to get herself, Lyon and maybe even Norway to the top.
content: Ada Hegerberg apologizes in advance for the forthcoming cliché. She knows it sounds trite, exactly what she would be expected to say, given all that she has been through. It is what everyone says, after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Evergrande says it will delay its financial report.
description: The news is the latest setback for the hugely indebted Chinese property developer, which fell into default last year.
content: China Evergrande, the giant embattled property developer, will not be able to publish its annual financial results on time, the company said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Help a Child With Math Anxiety
description: Approach calculations with curiosity, playfulness and a sense of adventure. Avoid too much homework.
content: “The worst thing to do is create situations of pressure, intimidation, high emotion, frustration and raised voices,” says Daniel Ansari, a professor of psychology and education at the University of Western Ontario, who studies how humans develop mathematical skills. Math anxiety is a common psychophysiological reaction characterized by feelings of dread and apprehension, increased heart rate and sweating. Up to 30 percent of people report moderate to high levels of math anxiety, a condition researchers have observed in children as young as 6. In brain-image scans, math-anxious children show more activity in the amygdala, a part of the brain central to processing fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Reich
title: For Russian Aristocrats, Paris Was a Glittering Expat Playground — Until 1917
description: Helen Rappaport’s “After the Romanovs” explains why Paris became the gravitational center for exiles both before and after the Russian Revolution.
content: AFTER THE ROMANOVSRussian Exiles in Paris From the Belle Époque Through Revolution and War
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: The Rise of the Tucker Carlson Politician
description: Two Republican Senate candidates field-test a new message honed in the cable-news studio.
content: There are legal rules that govern political ads — say, the one that requires federal candidates to appear onscreen and “approve this message” — and then there are aesthetic rules. A candidate who’s touting education proposals, for instance, will invariably be shown sitting awkwardly in a kid-size chair, reading to elementary-school students. A promise to bring manufacturing jobs back to the United States must be accompanied by footage of the candidate, preferably in a hard hat, nodding meaningfully at someone in a factory. The candidate should always appear with people — talking, listening, shaking hands — except when speaking directly to the viewer, which should be done from a living room, with a credenza cluttered with family photos in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Willy Chavarria Represents
description: With a powerful new collection, the queer Latinx designer muscles his way into the history of American fashion.
content: There is a thought that is never far from mind at a Willy Chavarria show like the one held on Friday at the Prince George Ballroom in the Flatiron district of Manhattan — under hot lights and in a haze of incense laced with the aroma of weed. And that thought is how in mainstream culture people are so often shrunken or displaced or miniaturized or marginalized until they become invisible even to themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl and Christine Chung
title: Tornado Cuts Destructive Path Through New Orleans as Storms Threaten South
description: At least one person was killed as a storm damaged homes, knocked out power and prompted a search for residents who may be trapped.
content: NEW ORLEANS — A tornado touched down in the New Orleans area on Tuesday night, passing through the city and killing at least one person, heavily damaging homes, knocking out power and prompting a search for residents who may be trapped, according to local authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Frieden
title: The Next Covid Wave Is Probably Already on Its Way
description: Infections may rise in the United States. How it plays out is up to us.
content: The most important lesson of the Covid pandemic is that the only constant is change. Variants spread, cases surge and abate, treatments change and knowledge expands. This means that we — the public, elected officials and public health leaders — need to learn constantly and adapt quickly, acting on the insight that no one policy response is likely to stay effective for long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Two Religious Conservatives and a Marxist Walk Into a Journal
description: Compact, a new online magazine edited by two religious conservatives and a Marxist proponent of “labor populism,” aims to challenge both “a libertine left and a libertarian right.”
content: Plenty of small media start-ups these days believe they can deliver the final blow to the tottering neoliberal order. But Compact, a self-described “radical American journal” debuting this week, is taking an unusual cross-ideological approach to the task of challenging, as a note from its editors puts it, “the overclass that controls government, culture, and capital.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Plans Sanctions on Russian Lawmakers as He Heads to Europe
description: A chief goal of the meetings this week is to show that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will not lead to sniping and disagreement among the United States and its allies.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden will announce sanctions this week on hundreds of members of Russia’s lower house of Parliament, according to a White House official familiar with the announcement, as the United States and its allies reach for even stronger measures to punish President Vladimir V. Putin for his monthlong invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: In Warsaw, a Network of Support Greets Those Crossing the Polish Border
description: A sprawling expo center in the Polish capital has given some 25,000 refugees a safe place to recharge before journeying on.
content: WARSAW — Ilona Yurchenkov, 28, sits on a black chair in a sprawling expo center on the outskirts of Warsaw, a Yankees hat on her head and her cat, Mars, in a pet carrier beside her. She left her home in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv when fighting began there, and she has been on the road for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Human Migration Brought Maize to Maya Region, Study Finds
description: A new analysis of the DNA of the remains of ancient people in the jungles of Belize reveals that farming technology arrived from the south.
content: The tropics are a paradise for everyone but a skeleton. Humidity keeps rainforests green but does little to preserve bodies, leading to a dearth of ancient skeletal remains in Neotropical regions such as Central America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Elon Musk opens Tesla’s first European plant, near Berlin.
description: The $7 billion plant will eventually produce half a million S.U.V.s a year, the company said.
content: BERLIN — Tesla officially began making cars in Europe on Tuesday, opening an assembly plant in a critical market where Elon Musk, the chief executive, plans to build 500,000 electric vehicles a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Likely Not Made by a Tyrannosaurus Rex
description: Adam Wagner’s puzzle will pull you in.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I am delighted to welcome Adam Wagner back to the New York Times Crossword for his seventh appearance in just under a year — that’s a pretty impressive track record! Mr. Wagner’s puzzles never fail to make me smile, and there’s always something fresh or novel about them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: By Turns Cautious and Confident, Judge Jackson Takes the Stage
description: In her first day of responding to senators’ questions, the judge gave few hints about her judicial philosophy but spoke forcefully about public safety and terrorism.
content: WASHINGTON — Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson alternated between two kinds of answers on her first day of facing questions at her Supreme Court confirmation hearing on Tuesday. On legal issues, she was opaque and noncommittal, emphasizing the limits of the judicial role.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Earn Tens of Thousands by Turning in Idling Trucks
description: A New York City clean air program is providing a well-paid gig to “idling warriors” who blow the whistle on polluting vehicles.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about urban bounty hunters who search for trucks that are parked with their engines running. We’ll also look at a photographer’s images of encounters during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: A Starbucks store in Seattle, the company’s hometown, votes to unionize.
description: The 9-0 tally was the seventh union victory in the U.S. in a push that began last year.
content: Employees at a Starbucks store in Seattle have voted to unionize, the latest group to do so in a union push that appears to be gaining steam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Will Getting Botox Now Prevent Future Wrinkles?
description: Or are injections just a temporary, addictive fix?
content: Q: Will Botox injections in my 20s or 30s mean smoother skin and fewer wrinkles down the line?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong and Ashley Southall
title: Woman Is Charged in Shoving Death of Broadway Singing Coach
description: Lauren Pazienza, 26, turned herself in and was charged with manslaughter in the death of Barbara Maier Gustern, 87.
content: After she pushed an elderly woman down and left her bleeding on the pavement, Lauren Pazienza took the train home to her apartment in Queens, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1972: Millions of Workers Strike in Italy
description: Farm laborers, pressing demands including a shorter working week and a minimum wage, staged a 24-hour walkout. Refinery and filling station employees were also striking over pay and hours.
content: ROME, March 21 (UPI).—Seven million farm and industrial workers walked out today in a strike barely noticed by the man in the street. But motorists were more concerned by refinery and filling station strikes which may cause an Easter season gasoline shortage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: 6 Oklahoma High School Students Killed in Crash
description: The small passenger vehicle the girls were in collided with a semi-truck in Tishomingo, Okla., the authorities said.
content: Six high school students were killed in a crash on Tuesday when the vehicle they were in collided with a semi-truck in Tishomingo, Okla., a rural city about 120 miles southeast of Oklahoma City, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Empty City Was Our Playground’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Our schedules were opposite: office and restaurant. But then the world shut down, and the dining rooms were closed. When Aiesha would normally be waiting tables, we were riding our bikes through Little Rock’s empty downtown. Logging off from my remote work felt like hearing a school bell ring. The empty city was our playground. I remember riding our bikes along the Arkansas River in the dark with a huge smile on my face. It was the best kind of smile, unseen and electric. Somehow, I knew happiness within a tragedy. I found my best friend. — Kim Mai Draheim
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Niraj Chokshi
title: What We Know About the Crash of China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735
description: The crash of the Boeing plane, with more than 130 people on board, is China’s worst air disaster in more than a decade.
content: China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735 was making a short trip between two cities in southern China on Monday, cruising at an altitude of more than 29,000 feet, when it began a violent plunge toward the earth. Residents in the area described hearing a boom, apparently from the plane crashing into a hillside, and then seeing smoke from the fires it had ignited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: MacKenzie Scott Gives $436 Million to Habitat for Humanity
description: The donation is part of an ongoing effort by Ms. Scott to give away her fortune.
content: MacKenzie Scott, who promised in 2019 that she would give away her fortune “until the safe is empty,” has donated $436 million to Habitat for Humanity International and its 84 affiliates, the organization said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. vaccination rates have stalled with another potential uptick coming.
description: The U.S. booster campaign has stalled, with about half of eligible adults still not boosted.
content: When the Covid vaccine first became widely available a year ago, it was a hopeful time, with demand exceeding capacity and millions of Americans jockeying for the nearest appointment slot. But, as of Monday, about a quarter of eligible adults were still not fully vaccinated, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: When Restaurants Are Closed on Mondays
description: New York City rarely shuts down, but the start of the week can be a dining challenge. Luckily, we’re here with recommendations.
content: Welcome to Where to Eat, the new newsletter about restaurants for The New York Times, with my recommendations! Chances are you don’t know me yet. I’m Nikita Richardson, an editor for the Food section. When people ask me why I got into food reporting — I was previously a staff writer at New York magazine’s Grub Street and an editor at Bon Appétit — my answer is simple: I love to eat, and I love to make it a whole event when I do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What’s Next for the Pandemic in California?
description: Wastewater testing reveals increasing levels of the coronavirus in the state.
content: When my friend texted me last week to say that she had a fever, I nearly discounted the possibility that she might have contracted Covid-19. The case numbers are so low in California right now, I thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex V. Cipolle
title: How Native Americans Are Trying to Debug A.I.’s Biases
description: Data on Native communities are not at the levels needed for accuracy in A.I.-driven tools. A group is trying to solve that problem.
content: This article is part of a limited series on artificial intelligence’s potential to solve everyday problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and François Halard
title: On Italy’s Adriatic Coast, an Ancestral Home on the Verge of a Second Act
description: The avant-garde curator Giorgio Pace has commissioned the architect Kengo Kuma to help him transform the 19th-century house into a museum.
content: GIORGIO PACE, A St. Moritz, Switzerland-based Italian art curator, is known for conceiving and executing unorthodox ideas that others might dismiss as undoable or absurd. Among his successes: a 2015 collaboration with the Parisian conceptual artist Pierre Huyghe and the self-described anarchitect François Roche, titled “What Could Happen,” for which Pace convinced Swiss Rail to run a 1910 private train with 300 hand-selected passengers — including the British architect Norman Foster, the collector Maja Hoffmann and the fashion designer Rick Owens — to a frozen Alpine lake for a performance with a naked actor crawling into an igloo to a soundtrack of recorded screams. For his 2011 show at the Chesa Planta museum near St. Moritz, “A Lunatic on Bulbs,” inspired by the Emily Dickinson line about her gardening habits, eight artists, including Rirkrit Tiravanija and Joel Shapiro, created idiosyncratic outdoor objects like a liquid-rubber-coated Ping-Pong table and a tire swing hoisted by solid gold chains. And for more than a decade, Pace, who earlier in his career worked for both the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Guggenheim in New York, has also run Nomad, an itinerant biannual design fair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz
title: As Russia Stalls in Ukraine, Dissent Brews Over Putin’s Leadership
description: Military losses have mounted, progress has slowed, and a blame game has begun among some Russian supporters of the war.
content: In January, the head of a group of serving and retired Russian military officers declared that invading Ukraine would be “pointless and extremely dangerous.” It would kill thousands, he said, make Russians and Ukrainians enemies for life, risk a war with NATO and threaten “the existence of Russia itself as a state.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: Is Geometry a Language That Only Humans Know?
description: Neuroscientists are exploring whether shapes like squares and rectangles — and our ability to recognize them — are part of what makes our species special.
content: During a workshop last fall at the Vatican, Stanislas Dehaene, a cognitive neuroscientist with the Collège de France, gave a presentation chronicling his quest to understand what makes humans — for better or worse — so special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Questioning Judge Jackson, Republicans give a preview of attack lines in the November election.
description: G.O.P. senators are pressing Judge Jackson on critical race theory and transgender rights, teeing up their attacks on Democrats as extremists.
content: As they begin questioning Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson on Tuesday, Republican senators are previewing many of the attack lines their party plans to use in the midterm congressional elections to portray Democrats as extremists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Yvan Colonna, Corsican Jailed for French Prefect’s Murder, Dies at 61
description: A folk hero for Corsica’s nationalist movement, he evaded a long manhunt but was finally arrested in 2003. He died shortly after being brutally attacked in prison.
content: PARIS — Yvan Colonna, a Corsican activist who was convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the murder of a top French official, and who became a symbol of Corsica’s nationalist movement and of the Mediterranean island’s ambivalent relations with mainland France, died on Monday in a hospital in Marseille. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Luke Vander Ploeg, Jessica Cheung, Paige Cowett, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Brad Fisher, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Will Sanctioning Oligarchs Change the War?
description: In punishment for the invasion of Ukraine, rich businessmen with ties to the Kremlin have been financially blacklisted.
content: Among the actions taken by the West to punish Moscow for the invasion of Ukraine is the blacklisting of the incredibly rich and politically connected Russian businessmen known as oligarchs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: A Return to Even Less Enlightened Eras
description: Three new historical novels whisk readers back to the Civil War, World War II and medieval times.
content: The freshly liberated narrator of David Wright Faladé’s stirring Civil War novel BLACK CLOUD RISING (Atlantic Monthly Press, 304 pp., $27) has much more than emancipation on his mind. Raised on North Carolina’s Outer Banks, a region with its own distinct traditions, “as remote from the mainland South as it was from the far-off North,” Richard Etheridge is also struggling with a deep sense of emotional isolation. Although he’s the son of an enslaved woman, he proudly bears the last name of the white father who owned him. A sergeant in the recently formed African Brigade, he owes his position less to his stature among his comrades than to the education imparted by his white half sister. “How much,” he’s forced to ask himself, “did I hate my own skin?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: Food Businesses Lose Faith in Instagram After Algorithm Changes
description: Instagram’s choice to prioritize videos over photos creates unforeseen costs for small companies, leaving many owners disheartened.
content: Sana Javeri Kadri leaned heavily on Instagram for marketing when she started her spice company, Diaspora Company, in 2017. “I completely credit them for our growth — and then the algorithm changed and our sales dropped horrifyingly,” she said. “There was a point where I was having dreams that Instagram could go back to the way things were, and my nightmares were about all the reasons why that was impossible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Reid
title: Too Much Screen Time? Landline Phones Offer a Lifeline.
description: Like record players and VHS tapes, landline phones are being embraced by nostalgic fans as an antidote to an increasingly digital way of life.
content: First came the rhinestone-encrusted rotary. Then the cherry-red lips. After that, the cheeseburger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Justin and Ben Smith pick a name for their media start-up.
description: The name, Semafor, a variation on the word “semaphore,” appears in similar form in many languages.
content: Justin Smith and Ben Smith, co-proprietors of a new media start-up that has captured the attention of the online news world, revealed on Tuesday the name for their venture: Semafor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Patrick Kingsley
title: Leaders of Israel, U.A.E. and Egypt Meet for Their First Summit
description: All three countries are navigating fraught relationships with the Biden administration amid the quickly changing geopolitical landscape precipitated by Russia’s war on Ukraine.
content: CAIRO — Egypt hosted the first summit meeting with leaders of Israel and the United Arab Emirates on Monday and Tuesday, the latest sign of a swift realignment of Middle Eastern political alliances since Israel established diplomatic relations in 2020 with several Arab countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Pompeii Moves With the Times’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about efforts at the historical site to examine gender, race and class, while also saving the ruins from the effects of climate change.
content: Featured Article: “Pompeii Moves With the Times” by Elisabetta Povoledo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angus Trumble
title: Two Forgers and a Small Crocodile Walk Into a Sauna
description: In María Gainza’s mystery “Portrait of an Unknown Lady,” the truth of Buenos Aires’s shady art underworld is in the eye of the beholder.
content: PORTRAIT OF AN UNKNOWN LADYBy María GainzaTranslated by Thomas Bunstead
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charley Locke
title: Commonplace Books Are Like a Diary Without the Risk of Annoying Yourself
description: I keep a journal of quotes, lines from songs, poetry. Nothing is my original thought — but all of it struck me as meaningful when I wrote it down.
content: I’ve never been a journal person, though not for lack of trying. A monogrammed duffel bag in my parents’ basement holds many old diaries — a furry leopard-print one from elementary school, Moleskines with unbroken spines from college — each with an optimistic entry or two. But the habit has never stuck. That’s partly down to a lack of discipline, but I think it’s mostly self-consciousness. I can’t help reading whatever I’m writing as some future-me would, rolling her eyes, condescending from the other side of whatever dilemma I’m going through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Cruz and Jackson spar over antiracism curriculum at a private school.
description: A question about whether or not infants were racist drew an audible sigh from the nominee for the Supreme Court.
content: For hours on Tuesday, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson fielded repeated questions from senators, some more emotional than others, about her past sentencing in child sex abuse cases, her defense of detainees at Guantánamo Bay and the details of her faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: A New Iran Deal Leaves Us Meeker and Weaker
description: A new pact would strengthen the world’s antidemocratic axis.
content: What does President Biden think he will get out of a new nuclear deal with Iran?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: At Casa Dani, Masterly Spanish Cooking in Globe-Trotting Garb
description: Leaving aside the gels, powders and liquid nitrogen that won him renown, the chef Dani García returns to his culinary roots.
content: The Andalusian chef Dani García has come back to establish a Manhattan beachhead nine years after his first attempt, Manzanilla. That was in 2013. A member of the scientific-technical school of Spanish cooking, Mr. García was best known at the time for introducing liquid nitrogen to the kitchen in edible fabrications like the Tomato Garden, three squat orbs that looked like miniature tomatoes but were not. One was fashioned from beets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson
title: Two Teachers Killed at a School in Sweden
description: The police said they were still trying to determine a motive for the attack in the southern city of Malmo.
content: BASTAD, Sweden — Two teachers were killed at a high school in Malmo in southern Sweden, and a student was arrested on suspicion of murder, the police said Tuesday. The motive for the attack was unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: ‘Harry Potter for Adults’: Netflix Lures ‘Bridgerton’ Fans With Live Events
description: A royal ball inspired by the popular Shonda Rhimes show aims to encourage the kind of water-cooler buzz that streaming services have struggled to create.
content: LOS ANGELES — The wisteria drips from the archway while classical music plays over the loudspeakers. Powder-wigged valets present champagne to guests who gaze at Empire-waist dresses, peer into a room filled with makeup and accessories or head to a stage for a quick oil portrait (actually a digital photo with a Regency England-esque filter).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Burbank
title: The Grand Theory Driving Putin to War
description: The goal, plainly, is empire.
content: President Vladimir Putin’s bloody assault on Ukraine, nearly a month in, still seems inexplicable. Rockets raining down on apartment buildings and fleeing families are now Russia’s face to the world. What could induce Russia to take such a fateful step, effectively electing to become a pariah state?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith
title: Another Theranos Trial Begins, This Time Without the Fanfare
description: Prosecutors say Ramesh Balwani worked hand in hand with Elizabeth Holmes, the Theranos chief executive, who was convicted of four counts of fraud.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A small group with cameras milled around on the sidewalk. Inside, a smattering of reporters stared into their phones. And when the defendant walked in, flanked by lawyers, barely anyone noticed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Here are the latest developments.
description: As Russian forces struggled to make progress across Ukraine, losing control of a contested town west of the capital, Moscow advanced on a different front on Tuesday, expanding the toughest crackdown on dissent during President Vladimir V. Putin’s 22 years in power.
content: As Russian forces struggled to make progress across Ukraine, losing control of a contested town west of the capital, Moscow advanced on a different front on Tuesday, expanding the toughest crackdown on dissent during President Vladimir V. Putin’s 22 years in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Bisping: The Michael Bisping Story’ Review: An M.M.A. Fighter Speaks Out
description: A documentary takes a look at Bisping’s tough and tender sides.
content: This slick documentary about the mixed martial arts fighter Michael Bisping spends a lot of its first half putting up a kind of cinematic “Tough Guys Only” sign. Bisping’s a crudely voluble bruiser from the North of England! His father was a sniper in the British Army! “Fighting is something that I liked, to be honest,” Bisping says, when not swearing at his critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Employees Walk Out Amid Furor Over Florida Legislation
description: Hoping to avoid controversy, the company initially shied away from taking a public stance on the anti-L.G.B.T.Q. bill. Now, an internal outcry has stretched into its third week.
content: Several weeks ago, before the Walt Disney Company became entangled in a battle over anti-L.G.B.T.Q. legislation in Florida — one that continued on Tuesday with walkouts by Disney employees — longtime theme park executives worried there could be trouble ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley
title: China Takes a Back Seat in International Diplomacy Over Ukraine
description: Despite its economic and military might and close ties to Russia, China has balked at trying to press Vladimir Putin to stop the fighting.
content: China has repeatedly called for peace talks in Ukraine. What it has not done is press Russia to negotiate an end to a war that has already cost thousands of lives, displaced millions and threatened to disrupt the world’s economy and even food security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jackson emphatically rejects allegations that she has been lenient on child sex abuse defendants.
description: “Nothing could be further from the truth,” she told the Senate Judiciary Committee.
content: Judge Jackson gave a lengthy and emphatic counter on Tuesday to Republican accusations that she has been lenient in sentencing defendants in child sex-abuse cases, using her first chance to address the matter before the Senate Judiciary Committee to assert that “nothing could be further from the truth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. scales back metal tariffs as Britain lifts duties on American whiskey and jeans.
description: The step, announced as U.S. and British officials met in Baltimore, removed trade barriers erected under former President Donald J. Trump.
content: The Biden administration said on Tuesday that it would roll back Trump-era tariffs on British steel and aluminum, moving to resolve a trans-Atlantic trade clash that had soured relations with a key ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Four Killed in Southern Israel in Latest in Spate of Attacks
description: The attacks have heightened fears of further violence in April, when the convergence of three religious holidays has leaders on edge.
content: JERUSALEM — Four Israelis were killed in a knife and car-ramming attack in Beersheba, in southern Israel, on Tuesday afternoon, in the third attack on Israeli Jews in less than a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Renate Raman and Joren Slaets
title: At ‘Grief Camp,’ Kids Learn to Process Loss Together
description: Yaren, age 10, lost her mother at 6. She felt alone in her grief — until she attended a camp for kids who have lost someone important.
content: Three years ago, we came across a short article about Missing You, a summer camp in Belgium where children struggling with grief can come together and bond with their peers. It struck us as an incredibly pure idea, and we wanted to know more. What does a grief camp look like? Is it a sullen, sad affair? Does it really help the children? And what do they do there?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Ribs Republicans Over Ketanji Brown Jackson
description: Kimmel said Jackson’s Supreme Court confirmation hearings could make the G.O.P.’s worst nightmare could come true: “Having this decided by two Black women whose names they can’t pronounce.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Echoing Conservative Grievances, Blackburn Miscasts Jackson’s Views
description: Senator Marsha Blackburn took quotes out of context as she levied a blistering attack against Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Marsha Blackburn, Republican of Tennessee, ripped into Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson on Monday during her Supreme Court confirmation hearing, tying the nominee to a wide range of conservative grievances. But the lawmaker’s accusations appeared to often be based on quotes taken out of context. Here’s a closer look at some of her apparent sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: How Ukraine’s Outgunned Air Force Is Fighting Back Against Russian Jets
description: Aerial dogfights. Top Gun-style duels. Ukraine’s fighter pilots are badly outnumbered but have so far kept Russia from controlling the skies.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Each night, Ukrainian pilots like Andriy loiter in an undisclosed aircraft hangar, waiting, waiting, until the tension is broken with a shouted, one-word command: “Air!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s Cricket-Star-Turned-Prime Minister Fights for Survival
description: Soaring inflation and a rift with the military threaten Imran Khan’s tenure as prime minister. He has dismissed criticism as a foreign conspiracy.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan is fighting for his political survival after opposition political parties have moved for a no-confidence motion in Parliament and the country’s powerful military has withdrawn its support for his government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Powers Remain and Threats Lurk as Women’s Sweet 16 Is Set
description: Sure, South Carolina and UConn are among the schools still in the mix — but so are the upset magicians South Dakota and Creighton.
content: BATON ROUGE, La. — The Pete Maravich Assembly Center has spent 50 years seeing commencements and concerts, presidential power and a governor’s prayer rally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Do You Think of Pet Weddings?
description: The events have recently become more popular. Why do you think that is? Would you attend or even host one?
content: You’re about to read an article that describes the growing trend of weddings for people’s animals, including cats, dogs and even cows. In one ceremony, 80 canine pairs were united in marriage. But before you read the article, finish this sentence: Animal weddings are ______.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Russia’s combat force has shrunk, a Pentagon official says, reflecting casualties and other struggles.
description: The official said that Russian forces were “struggling on many fronts,” and that there were indications that some troops had been evacuated with frostbite.
content: The Pentagon has assessed that Russia’s “combat power” in Ukraine — comprising more than 150,000 troops massed in Belarus and western Russian prior to the invasion — has dipped below 90 percent of its original force for the first time, reflecting the losses Russian troops have suffered at the hands of Ukrainian soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Zelensky condemns Russian attacks on protesters and children.
description: ‘It was a day of difficult events,’ the Ukrainian president said in a video address.
content: In a video address shared online early Tuesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine condemned Russian attacks on protesters in the city of Kherson in the south and strikes in the Zaporizhzhia region in the southeast, where four children were hospitalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: What to Watch For on Day 2 of Jackson’s Confirmation Hearing
description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will answer her first questions from senators on Tuesday.
content: After a day of tone-setting opening statements, Day 2 of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Supreme Court confirmation hearing promises to steer deeper into substance, and possibly partisan fighting, as the 22 members of the Senate Judiciary Committee question the nominee on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Chris Madden, Lifestyle Author and Personality, Dies at 73
description: An early HGTV host, she lent her name to furniture and housewares lines. In the late 1990s, her book on women’s private sanctuaries touched a nerve.
content: Chris Madden, a lifestyle and decorating author and personality who lent her name to furniture and housewares, including a collection for J.C. Penney, and was an early program host on HGTV, the addictive cable network devoted to the home, died on March 2 in Vero Beach, Fla. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: No Survivors Found in China Eastern Crash, Officials Say
description: Workers recovered identity cards, cellphones and purses from the crash site. But the plane’s steep plunge suggested there was a “minuscule” chance of any survivors, an expert said.
content: Emergency workers have found no survivors more than 24 hours after a Boeing 737 plane carrying 132 people crashed in southern China, officials said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Conway, Andrea Urbez and Hisato Tasaka
title: Up Next for Jessie Buckley: More Movies, and Music
description: This summer, the multitalented actress and Oscar nominee will release an album with Bernard Butler.
content: The actress Jessie Buckley is a natural brunette, but her hair is currently chopped into a ragged black bob and her nails are painted the same emerald green that the writer Christopher Isherwood gave Sally Bowles, the glamorously in-denial singer, in his 1937 novella of the same name. “Different hair for every job,” says Buckley, characteristically wry over a video call from London. “People think you’re very transformative.” Later, she’ll go onstage in “Cabaret,” the musical adaptation of Isherwood’s story of Weimar-era doom, at the Playhouse Theatre’s Kit Kat Club, alongside Eddie Redmayne. And in a few weeks, she’ll fly to Los Angeles for the 94th Academy Awards: Her performance in “The Lost Daughter” garnered her a nomination for best actress in a supporting role. Her brother had delivered the news to her over text the day before. “I thought he was joking,” she says. “It’s just something that doesn’t happen in life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Eduardo Medina
title: Bucking Republican Trend, Indiana Governor Vetoes Transgender Sports Bill
description: Gov. Eric Holcomb nixed legislation that would have blocked transgender girls from playing school sports. Eleven states have enacted similar bills.
content: Gov. Eric Holcomb of Indiana vetoed a bill on Monday that would have banned transgender girls from competing in school-sanctioned girls’ sports, taking a sharply different approach to the issue than 11 fellow Republican governors who have signed similar measures into law in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Daughter Is Having Sex With Her Best Friend. Must I Tell Her Mom?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to keep your teenager’s sexual relationship secret  — and more.
content: My daughter is in a newly romantic relationship with her best friend, who is also female. Both are in their midteens. My daughter recently confided in me that they have had sex. She insists, however, that I am not allowed to tell the friend’s mother, because the mother wouldn’t let them have sleepovers or hang out as much. My ex-husband is the one who hosts the sleepovers, and he looks the other way when they are in the bedroom, reasoning that (or so my daughter tells me), “It’s OK because there are no penises involved.” I am not as close with the friend’s mother as my ex-husband is, but we are friendly. Am I obligated to tell this woman the truth about the nature of our daughters’ friendship? Are my ex-husband’s actions egregious? Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Utah Governor Vetoes Transgender-Athlete Bill
description: The bill would have barred transgender athletes from competing in girls’ sports. Gov. Spencer Cox, a Republican, rejected the measure passed by lawmakers in his party.
content: Gov. Spencer Cox of Utah vetoed a bill on Tuesday that would have barred young transgender athletes from participating in girls’ sports, becoming the second Republican governor in two days to reject such legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Kirchick
title: When Reagan Said Gay
description: In the 1970s the Republican Party tried to muzzle gay identity.
content: On March 8, the Florida Senate passed the innocuously named Parental Rights in Education Act, which Gov. Ron DeSantis is expected to sign into law. Dubbed the “Don’t Say Gay” bill by critics, the legislation mandates that “classroom instruction by school personnel or third parties on sexual orientation or gender identity may not occur in kindergarten through grade 3 or in a manner that is not age appropriate or developmentally appropriate for students in accordance with state standards.” By permitting parents to sue school districts that fail to enforce its vague provisions, the act effectively bars classroom discussion and individual expression on a wide range of subjects not necessarily limited to homosexuality and gender identity. Gay students and the children of same-sex couples, for instance, would likely be inhibited from talking about their lives, and teachers could face the wrath of angry parents simply for discussing historical events involving gay people, such as the deadly 2016 attack on a gay nightclub in Orlando.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Ukrainians Try to Push Back Russian Forces Pummeling Their Cities
description: Desperate fighting has shifted the front lines but neither side seems to have a decisive upper hand as Ukraine’s suffering deepens.
content: Ukrainian forces pressed to thwart the Russian invasion, mounting counteroffensives on multiple fronts and retaking a town outside of Kyiv on Tuesday, while the more heavily armed Russians, unable so far to gain a decisive upper hand, tried to pound Ukraine’s cities and people into submission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Madrid
title: While Democrats Debate ‘Latinx,’ Latinos Head to the G.O.P.
description: The Democrats’ problem with Latinos.
content: Democrats working to save their slim majority in the House in November’s elections have been sounding alarms lately over research showing that Republican attacks on culture-war issues are working, particularly with center-left, Hispanic and independent voters. Hispanic voters, many of us alienated by progressive labels and mottos like “Latinx” and “defund the police,” have been drifting rightward as Donald Trump marginally increased the G.O.P. Hispanic vote share in 2016 and again in 2020 — a phenomenon, it should be noted, that goes beyond Mr. Trump or any individual campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Odessa and the Ukraine That Should Have Been
description: How history cut off the rise of a great city.
content: Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has sent the prices of many commodities skyrocketing. And it’s not just oil and gas. From a humanitarian point of view, the soaring price of food, especially wheat, may be an even bigger problem. Before the war, Russia and Ukraine produced almost a quarter of the world’s wheat, much of it exported. Both the direct effects of the war and the sanctions imposed on Russia are disrupting that supply; nobody knows how long this disruption may last or how much suffering high food prices will cause around the world, especially in poor countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: demeanor
description: This word has appeared in 185 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word demeanor has appeared in 185 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 12 in “How Ukrainian Paralympians Pushed Through Fear and Worry” by David Waldstein:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Stanley Reed
title: Will War Make Europe’s Switch to Clean Energy Even Harder?
description: A wind turbine factory in Denmark and a coal mine in Poland illustrate the painful policy choices after Russia’s aggression in Ukraine added urgency to the transition to greener energy.
content: At the Siemens Gamesa factory in Aalborg, Denmark, where the next generation of offshore wind turbines is being built, workers are on their hands and knees inside a shallow, canoe-shaped pod that stretches the length of a football field. It is a mold used to produce one half of a single propeller blade. Guided by laser markings, the crew is lining the sides with panels of balsa wood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Extends Navalny’s Sentence
description: Plus Pfizer’s plan to send Covid pills to poor countries and efforts to unseat Pakistan’s leader.
content: A Russian court sentenced the already imprisoned opposition leader Aleksei Navalny to nine years in prison on fraud charges, a move widely seen as a way for the Kremlin to more tightly control the war’s narrative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: How Emily Nunn Turned Salad Into a Soapbox
description: Brash and funny, she uses her popular Substack newsletter, The Department of Salad, to hold forth about ageism, politics and, oh yes, leafy greens.
content: ATLANTA — Emily Nunn won’t drive on the freeways here, so it can take 45 minutes to get from her apartment to the cavernous indoor Your Dekalb Farmers Market, whose inexpensive and bountiful produce selection she prefers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Soccer’s Richest Clubs Sidestep Salary Caps in New Cost Controls
description: UEFA’s new financial regulations will tie spending to club revenues, entrenching the advantages wealthy clubs already enjoy in the market for talent.
content: The biggest reforms of European soccer’s financial controls in a generation will stop short of creating U.S.-style salary caps to restrain teams’ spending, and instead will enact rules that are unlikely to stop the continent’s richest clubs from buying up the best talent and winning the most coveted trophies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Daniel Yergin Thinks Russia’s Days as an Energy Superpower Might Be Over
description: The economic historian explains how Putin’s invasion of Ukraine is affecting energy markets and what that means for geopolitics — and climate change.
content: Nearly every dimension of the Ukraine-Russia conflict has been shaped by energy markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Russia’s shrinking invasion force
description: Russia’s combat power has dropped because of significant losses, a U.S. defense official says.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Carol Rosenberg and Linda Qiu
title: Here’s the context behind what Judge Jackson wrote about war crimes.
description: Two Republicans asserted during the second day of confirmation hearings on Tuesday that Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson had called former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and former President George W. Bush “war criminals.” But she never used that phrase.
content: Two Republicans claimed during the second day of confirmation hearings on Tuesday that Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson had called former defense secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and former President George W. Bush “war criminals.” But she never used that phrase. Here is the context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Snowboarding Coach Faces New Accusations of Sexual Misconduct
description: Peter Foley, already accused of coercing athletes into posing for nude photos, now faces scrutiny from more women. He has been relieved of his duties as a U.S. Olympic coach.
content: Longtime U.S. Olympic snowboarding coach Peter Foley, accused of sexual misconduct by a former athlete during the Winter Games in February and relieved of his duties over the weekend, faces a broader, formal investigation into new allegations of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Ahead of French Open, an Injury Interrupts Nadal’s Surge
description: Two days after the end of his 20-match win streak to start the season, Nadal said a rib injury would keep him out for four to six weeks, a timeline that would disrupt his clay-court season.
content: SAN DIEGO — Rafael Nadal, the 21-time Grand Slam tournament singles champion, announced Tuesday that he had a stress fracture in his rib cage and would not play for “four to six weeks.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Daniel Yergin
description: A conversation with economic historian Daniel Yergin.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Daniel Yergin. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Rival Sept. 11 Victims Near Potential Deal to Divide Afghan Central Bank Assets
description: But another group opposes it. A court has not yet decided whether $3.5 billion in Afghan central bank funds can be used to pay Taliban debts.
content: WASHINGTON — At least six major groups of victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks have struck a tentative deal to divide about $3.5 billion in Afghan central bank assets they are trying to seize to pay off legal claims against the Taliban, according to a letter filed on Tuesday to a judge overseeing the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Hudson Felt Too Much Like a City, So It Was Time for a New Upstate Retreat
description: Anthony D’Argenzio, known for Zio and Sons and This Old Hudson, and his family have a new old house — and it’s not far from their old old house, in Hudson, N.Y.
content: When Anthony D’Argenzio began visiting Hudson, N.Y., with its aged brick buildings, antiques shops and growing cultural scene, about a decade ago, it seemed like more than just a nice place to spend some time. It was somewhere, he thought, that he could realize his creative and entrepreneurial dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why KBJ Is Different
description: Ketanji Brown Jackson is similar to and different from the justices she would be joining — not only because of her race and gender.
content: There have been three main career paths to becoming a federal judge in recent decades: defending corporate clients, serving as a prosecutor or working in politics. Many judges have followed more than one of the paths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: TotalEnergies says it will stop buying oil from Russia by the end of the year.
description: The French company said it had been accused of “complicity in war crimes” for continuing to work in Russia.
content: TotalEnergies, the French oil and gas company, said on Tuesday that it would stop buying Russian oil by the end of the year and halt further investment in projects in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Metaverse Lessons From Hollywood
description: Recreating the human face could give virtual interactions the sense of intimacy they’re missing.
content: Decades ago, Steve Perlman’s technology helped kick-start an era in which figments of Hollywood imagination feel increasingly authentic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Top Editors to Leave BuzzFeed News Ahead of Newsroom Cuts
description: Mark Schoofs, the site’s editor in chief, is among the departures. The chief executive said BuzzFeed News would need to “prioritize the areas of coverage our audience connects with the most.”
content: The head of BuzzFeed News and two other top editors are departing the company ahead of cuts to the newsroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau Strikes Accord With Opponents to Secure Hold on Power
description: A left-of-center opposition party agrees to back the government until 2025 in exchange for advancing its causes.
content: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada on Tuesday announced an alliance with a left-of-center opposition party that will give him the secure hold on power that eluded him in last year’s election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Valeriya Safronova
title: Aleksei Navalny, Fiery Putin Critic, Is Handed a New, 9-Year Prison Sentence
description: Despite already being behind bars, Mr. Navalny has been urging Russians to protest the war in Ukraine, making him even more of a liability for President Vladimir V. Putin.
content: A Russian court sentenced Aleksei A. Navalny to nine years in a high-security prison on Tuesday, imposing a new punishment on the imprisoned opposition leader at a time when the war in Ukraine has made him even more of a liability for President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: This Database Stores the DNA of 31,000 New Yorkers. Is It Illegal?
description: A database used by the New York Police Department violates state law and the Constitution, the Legal Aid Society contends in a lawsuit.
content: Three years ago, Shakira Leslie was returning home from a cousin’s birthday party in the Bronx when officers pulled over her friend’s car for a traffic infraction. After she got out of the back seat, the police searched her and found nothing illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Follow the global youth protests this week
description: Demonstrations are planned for Friday, so we looked at what drives the movement. Here are four takeaways.
content: They’ve grown up in a pandemic. They’ve come of age in an era of strongman leaders. The climate crisis looms over their very lives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Skyrocketing Death Rate in Hong Kong Shows Importance of Vaccinating Seniors
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 22, 2022.
content: “Zero Covid is a really good strategy if you can stay at zero. But as we found in Hong Kong, it doesn’t last forever.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Miami Beach Announces Curfew After Spring Break Shootings
description: “We can’t endure this anymore, we just simply can’t,’’ said Mayor Dan Gelber. “This isn’t your father’s, your mother’s spring break. This is something totally different.”
content: Faced with an onslaught of spring break revelers, Miami Beach officials declared a state of emergency on Monday and announced a curfew for the city’s South Beach area after two shootings over the weekend that left five people wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Jen Psaki, White House Press Secretary, Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: Ms. Psaki said that she had two meetings with President Biden on Monday but that they had been socially distanced.
content: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday for the second time in five months, one day before she was scheduled to join President Biden on a diplomatic trip to Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Alcohol-Related Deaths Spiked During the Pandemic, a Study Shows
description: The deaths were up 25 percent in 2020 compared with 2019, amid heightened stress factors and delayed treatment, according to a new report.
content: Almost a million people in the United States have died of Covid-19 in the past two years, but the full impact of the pandemic’s collateral damage is still being tallied. Now a new study reports that the number of Americans who died of alcohol-related causes increased precipitously during the first year of the pandemic, as routines were disrupted, support networks frayed and treatment was delayed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Judging a Judge on Race and Crime, G.O.P. Plays to Base and Fringe
description: Grilling Ketanji Brown Jackson, the first Black woman nominated to the Supreme Court, conservative senators painted her as a jurist who had coddled criminals and embraced “woke” education.
content: WASHINGTON — After all of the entreaties from top Republicans to show respect at Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation hearings, Senator Ted Cruz on Tuesday afternoon chose to grill the first Black woman nominated for the Supreme Court on her views on critical race theory and insinuate that she was soft on child sexual abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Victor Fazio, Longtime Democratic Leader in the House, Dies at 79
description: Known for his ability to work across the aisle, he represented the Sacramento area from 1979 to 1999 and rose to become chairman of the House Democratic caucus.
content: Victor Fazio, a longtime Democratic member of Congress from California who served in House leadership for several years, died on March 16 at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Bhadra Sharma
title: Gurkha Veterans Fight a Colonial-Era Legacy Still Shaping Nepal
description: Nepal’s best and brightest have been recruited while young to fight for Britain for over 200 years, with their pay and pensions a fraction of their fellow British soldiers’ for much of that time.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — In one corner of Nepal’s capital, young men are going through the final preparations in pursuit of their singular lifelong dream: a place in the British Army as a Gurkha soldier, perceived as their ticket out of a life of uncertainty and poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: ‘OK Doomer’ and the Climate Advocates Who Say It’s Not Too Late
description: A growing chorus of young people is focusing on climate solutions. “‘It’s too late’ means ‘I don’t have to do anything, and the responsibility is off me.’”
content: Alaina Wood is well aware that, planetarily speaking, things aren’t looking so great. She’s read the dire climate reports, tracked cataclysmic weather events and gone through more than a few dark nights of the soul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Preschoolers Can Shed Their Masks, Mayor Adams Says
description: New York City plans to end the mask requirement for the city’s youngest children on April 4 if coronavirus cases remain low.
content: In his first months as mayor, Eric Adams has been almost singularly focused on New York City’s recovery from the pandemic, urging workers to return to offices and ending mask mandates for school-age children and vaccine mandates for restaurants and gyms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘At the Wedding’ Review: Cocktails, Dancing and an Albatross
description: A trenchant new comedy by Bryna Turner features Mary Wiseman in a comic tour-de-force as the guest most likely to make a scene.
content: “I’m starting to think this wedding needs a villain,” says Carlo, as if the one she has semi-crashed were a murder mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
title: Ukraine War and Pandemic Force Nations to Retreat From Globalization
description: Conflicts among the U.S., Russia and China — and endless Covid-19 outbreaks — strain the interdependent economy and Western ideas of post-Cold War stability.
content: WASHINGTON — When the Cold War ended, governments and companies believed that stronger global economic ties would lead to greater stability. But the Ukraine war and the pandemic are pushing the world in the opposite direction and upending those ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: How Charli XCX, Caroline Polachek and Christine and the Queens Navigate Pop
description: The friends and collaborators have taken very different paths in the music industry. Joining up on a track from Charli’s new album, “Crash,” they talked about their crucial camaraderie.
content: As she was preparing to release “Crash,” the glossiest album of her career as a solo pop artist, Charli XCX was in the doldrums. In December, the British singer and songwriter landed a high-stakes “Saturday Night Live” performance that would feature two of her friends and collaborators, Caroline Polachek and Christine and the Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Terra e Mare, With a Menu True to Its Name, Opens in Jersey City
description: Greg Baxtrom’s new comfort-food restaurant, a kaiseki-style spot from Hand Hospitality, and more restaurant news.
content: One advantage that the Jersey City waterfront has over Manhattan’s is the New York view, and now this restaurant in the Hudson House complex, an imposing, multistory event space run by Jeanne and Frank Cretella’s Landmark Hospitality, makes the most of just that. Steel, natural and reclaimed wood, leather and, above all, expansive windows define the space. Subtle maritime details in copper are also incorporated in the décor. (At the prow of the Port Liberte peninsula and pier, the restaurant can be reached by ferry.) Its executive chef is David C. Felton, who has worked on Hudson House private events since it reopened in 2021. His menu takes its marching orders from the restaurant’s name, meaning “land and sea” in Italian. Some of the turfside choices are porchetta, veal Parmesan on the bone, lamb steak, rib-eye with braised fennel, and a 16-ounce dry-aged strip steak. From the surf are raw bar selections, grilled octopus, poached prawns, bucatini with lobster, grilled tuna loin, and lobsters from a two-story tank to order grilled, wood-roasted or steamed. There are vegan and vegetarian items like farro risotto, cacio e pepe polenta, and celery root steak. The spacious bar is free-standing and seats 60. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Amanda Bynes, Former Child Star, Is Released From Conservatorship
description: A judge in California freed the former Nickelodeon star from the arrangement that had governed her life after highly publicized struggles with substance abuse.
content: A judge ruled on Tuesday to end the conservatorship that for the better part of a decade has governed the life of Amanda Bynes, who shot to fame as a child star on Nickelodeon and went on to have highly publicized struggles with substance abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Dance Company Looks to the Future With a New Artistic Team
description: The choreographer Nai-Ni Chen died in December. Now her company takes its next steps, beginning with a season at New York Live Arts.
content: In December, a shock rippled through dance circles when it was announced that the choreographer Nai-Ni Chen had died in a swimming accident in Hawaii while on vacation. A prolific dance artist specializing in both contemporary and traditional works, Chen, a youthful 62, was a powerful presence in the Chinese American dance community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Review: ‘Bruise & Thorn,’ a Gay Fantasia at a Laundromat
description: Hip-hop, impromptu duckwalks and loving shade fill C. Julian Jiménez’s new play about two cousins dreaming of escaping their day jobs.
content: At a combination Pizza Hut-Taco Bell in Jamaica, Queens, the gender-fluid Thorn works on a rap — hinged on the line “I gotta leave New York City” — that will hopefully lead to an escape by way of an “America’s Got Talent” victory. Because Thorn, a trans woman, is played with irresistible magnetism by the nightlife performer Jae W.B., it’s almost impossible not to back her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Vivien Leigh and Laurence Olivier’s Turbulent Relationship, Retold With Compassion
description: In “Truly, Madly,” Stephen Galloway writes about one of the 20th century’s most glamorous couples, training an eye on Leigh’s mental health struggles.
content: God help anyone who flew the friendly skies with Vivien Leigh, her second husband, Laurence Olivier, or both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: A Republican Fights Voter Fraud in His Race (231 Days Before Election Day)
description: In an audio recording obtained by The New York Times, Adam Laxalt, a Republican running for Senate in Nevada, said he’s already gearing up to fight election fraud.
content: We have an item tonight from our colleague Nick Corasaniti, who reports on how a Republican running for Senate in Nevada has been anticipating an election-fraud fight in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Music Man’ Sets Box Office Record for a Reopened Broadway
description: The Hugh Jackman-led revival has 76 trombones, 110 cornets, and took in $3.5 million in ticket sales last week, more than any show since the pandemic began.
content: Broadway has a new box office leader: A starry revival of “The Music Man” grossed $3.5 million last week, the most of any show since theaters reopened after the long pandemic shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Ina Garten Delights in Hitchcock Thrillers and Her Mini Cooper
description: With a new show coming to Discovery+, the Barefoot Contessa discussed her passion for French butter, Nordic dramas and a very American musical.
content: Here is how Ina Garten described her style of cooking: “It’s simple and elegant. I like things that are the essential flavors they’re supposed to be, but they taste better than you expect.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: ‘A Very Significant Moment for Business’
description: The S.E.C. has proposed sweeping new rules on company climate disclosures.
content: The S.E.C. voted yesterday on sweeping rule changes that would require public companies to disclose climate-related risks and greenhouse gas emissions. Though many already report some of this information, no mandatory standard exists, making it hard for investors to compare data across companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Virginia, the first state to set Covid workplace rules, drops them.
description: The rules required employers to mandate indoor masking in higher-risk areas and to report Covid outbreaks to the state’s Department of Health.
content: Virginia’s workplace safety board voted on Monday to withdraw the state’s emergency rules for protecting workers from Covid-19, leaving employers to follow looser guidelines to prevent the spread of the coronavirus in the workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: What’s the Deal With Masks on Planes?
description: Should mask rules on planes be lifted? Several British airlines have just suspended the requirement, but in the United States, the mandate, to be reviewed next month, remains. Here’s a look at where things stand.
content: Air travel has been one of the last holdouts for strict pandemic mask requirements. In the United States, for example, the mask mandate — which was recently extended to April 18, when it comes up for review again — is still enforced. Over the last year, 922 of those who didn’t wear masks received fines from the Transportation Security Administration, according to a report by the Government Accountability Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Mariupol refuses to surrender.
content: Residents of Mariupol, Ukraine, braced for renewed attacks after the Ukrainian government rejected Russia’s ultimatum to surrender the besieged and ravaged southern port city. Efforts to reach hundreds of thousands of people trapped there remained fraught with danger. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Kanye West’s Stormy Relationship With the Grammys Erupts Again
description: The musician, nominated for five awards, was told he will not be able to perform at the ceremony on April 3. The decision came after weeks of erratic and troubling public behavior.
content: When the latest Grammy nominations were announced in November, Kanye West picked up five nods, including album of the year, teeing up a potential reconciliation between one of pop music’s most mercurial stars and the institution he has spent much of the last two decades criticizing, challenging and sometimes outright insulting — even as West has yearned for its affirmation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Venezuelan Vacations Abruptly End as Tourists Return Home to a Different Russia
description: While Russian tourists were visiting Margarita Island, their country invaded Ukraine. Many were left wondering what travails awaited them back at home.
content: PLAYA PUERTO CRUZ, Venezuela — They drank rum and danced to a boombox blasting Russian electro pop music in a scrappy airport waiting hall. Singing “It’s Not Enough,” they enjoyed the last hours of their tropical holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Separate Together
description: Is “parallel play” good for adults?
content: The term parallel play usually refers to young children playing independently alongside one another. It informs how toddlers learn to interact with others, share and become social beings. And some believe it can be beneficial for adult relationships, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: On the Scene in Poland
description: A sprawling expo center in the Polish capital has given some 25,000 refugees a safe place to recharge before journeying on.
content: A sprawling expo center in the Polish capital has given some 25,000 refugees a safe place to recharge before journeying on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle and John Otis
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Sunshine Protection Act, Aviation Disaster, Invasive Species
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Instagram Influencer’s New Upstate Retreat
description: Anthony D’Argenzio has renovated a new old house for his family — and it’s not far from their old, old house, in Hudson, N.Y.
content: Anthony D’Argenzio has renovated a new old house for his family — and it’s not far from their old, old house, in Hudson, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seafood From the Coast of Spain
description: A new restaurant in the Manhattan West development, Casa Dani, celebrates black rice, tuna and other dishes from the Mediterranean.
content: A new restaurant in the Manhattan West development, Casa Dani, celebrates black rice, tuna and other dishes from the Mediterranean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden to Press Allies for Stronger Sanctions Against Russia
description: President Biden will join allies at a series of global summits in Europe where they are expected to announce new sanctions against Russia and tighten existing ones.
content: President Biden will join allies at a series of global summits in Europe where they are expected to announce new sanctions against Russia and tighten existing ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Network Pool
title: Judge Jackson Pushes Back Against G.O.P. Criticism Over Her Neutrality
description: On the second day of her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson defended her legal philosophy and faced questions about her religious faith from Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina.
content: On the second day of her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson defended her legal philosophy and faced questions about her religious faith from Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York City to End Mask Mandate for Preschool Children
description: Mayor Eric Adams said the school mask mandate will end for children under the age of 5 on April 4 as long as coronavirus cases remain low.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said the school mask mandate will end for children under the age of 5 on April 4 as long as coronavirus cases remain low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Powerful Storms and Tornadoes Rip Through Texas
description: A severe storm system injured several people and damaged structures in the state.
content: A severe storm system injured several people and damaged structures in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Renate Raman and Joren Slaets
title: Yaren and the Sun
description: Yaren, age 10, lost her mother at 6. She felt alone in her grief — until she attended a camp for kids who have lost someone important.
content: Yaren, age 10, lost her mother at 6. She felt alone in her grief — until she attended a camp for kids who have lost someone important.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Network Pool
title: Ted Cruz Spars With Judge Jackson Over ‘Antiracist Baby’ Book
description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, nominee for the Supreme Court, audibly sighed when questioned by Senator Ted Cruz of Texas about a children’s book he said is taught at the school where she sits on the board of trustees.
content: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, nominee for the Supreme Court, audibly sighed when questioned by Senator Ted Cruz of Texas about a children’s book he said is taught at the school where she sits on the board of trustees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 22, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 22, 2022.
content: An article on Monday about Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s academic career at Harvard misstated Barack Obama’s job when Judge Jackson met him in 1996. He was a lawyer, not a community organizer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Opioids, Chronic Pain and Addiction
description: Readers respond to a guest essay by Maia Szalavitz about the opioid crisis. Also: The Republicans and the Ukraine war.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 23, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 23, 2022.
content: An article on Saturday about Russian war tactics before its invasion of Ukraine mischaracterized an essay by Alexei Arbatov, a former Russian lawmaker. Mr. Arbatov was describing views held by the Russian leadership, not by himself.
source.name: The New York Times
